children.title: attitudes
children.comment: The ways in which people think or feel about something or someone and which affect their behaviour.

children.title: attitudes, God's to people
children.comment: Scripture indicates the ways in which God relates to people, often suggesting that these illustrate the ways in which believers should behave.

children.title: attitudes, positive to God
children.comment: Scripture identifies a range of positive attitudes towards God, which believers are encouraged to adopt.

children.title: attitudes, negative to God
children.comment: Scripture identifies a range of negative attitudes towards God, which believers are encouraged to avoid.

children.title: attitudes, to other people
children.comment: Scripture illustrates a range of attitudes towards other people, some of which are commended, while others are condemned.

children.title: attitudes, to life
children.comment: The way in which people think or feel about human life is of major importance to morality. Scripture declares the sanctity of life, and the attitudes towards life which should follow.

children.title: attitudes, in prayer
children.comment: Attitudes in prayer include both the postures people adopt while praying and the hopes that they have concerning its outcome. Scripture points to the need for humility and expectation on the part of those who pray.

children.title: Falling on one's face before God
attitudes, God's to people
children.comment: Scripture indicates the ways in which God relates to people, often suggesting that these illustrate the ways in which believers should behave.

children.title: attitudes, positive to God
children.comment: Scripture identifies a range of positive attitudes towards God, which believers are encouraged to adopt.

children.title: attitudes, negative to God
children.comment: Scripture identifies a range of negative attitudes towards God, which believers are encouraged to avoid.

children.title: attitudes, to other people
children.comment: Scripture illustrates a range of attitudes towards other people, some of which are commended, while others are condemned.

children.title: attitudes, to life
children.comment: The way in which people think or feel about human life is of major importance to morality. Scripture declares the sanctity of life, and the attitudes towards life which should follow.

children.title: attitudes, in prayer
children.comment: Attitudes in prayer include both the postures people adopt while praying and the hopes that they have concerning its outcome. Scripture points to the need for humility and expectation on the part of those who pray.

children.title: Falling on one's face before God
behaviour
children.comment: A person's actions or way of life. Good behaviour will not earn salvation, but believers must practise good behaviour in accordance with Scripture as evidence of their conversion. Scripture stresses that bad behaviour is inconsistent with Christian faith and urges believers to mend their ways.

cschildren.title: Good behaviour towards God is commanded
Good behaviour towards other people is commanded

seealsos.comment: Pr 10:1-31:31 contains much wisdom concerning good and bad behaviour

cschildren.title: Good behaviour does not earn salvation
Good behaviour confirms a believer's profession of faith

children.title: Obedience to Jesus Christ and his teachings
A believer has died to sin and is alive to God
abandonment
children.comment: The state and experience of being forsaken, shared by God as well as by human beings.

cschildren.title: God abandons those who forsake him
God shows mercy to those who have been justly abandoned
Those who feel abandoned by God
God promises never to abandon his people
Examples of people who were abandoned

children.title: abstinence
children.comment: The deliberate decision to do without something, especially as a form of spiritual discipline expressing commitment or repentance.

children.title: Israel's abstinence from certain sorts of meat

secondaryrefs.comment: God used the food laws to teach Peter a spiritual lesson.

children.title: Temporary sexual abstinence as a form of discipline
Voluntary abstinence for the sake of others
Israel's abstinence from certain sorts of meat

secondaryrefs.comment: God used the food laws to teach Peter a spiritual lesson.

children.title: Temporary sexual abstinence as a form of discipline
Voluntary abstinence for the sake of others
abuse
children.comment: The deliberate misuse of gifts or privileges, and the insulting of individuals. Scripture stresses that neither God's gifts nor his people are to be abused.

cschildren.title: The abuse of God and his people
The abuse of Christian freedom is condemned

children.title: Believers are required to resist sin
Grace does not give believers the freedom to sin

cschildren.title: The dangers of abusing Christian freedom

secondaryrefs.comment: as means of covering up evil

cschildren.title: Examples of the abuse of Christian freedom

children.title: achievement
children.comment: Human beings can achieve many things, though any achievement which disregards God is futile. God always achieves what he intends. Anything of eternal value needs God-given resources.

children.title: Human achievements can lead to pride
Human achievements can give false security
Human achievements do not lead to justification

primaryrefs.comment: God will overthrow all human achievement that is in opposition to him.

children.title: Achievements out of trials and sorrows
Achieving things with the help of fellow believers
admonition
children.comment: A loving attempt to correct another's attitude or behaviour. Christians are to admonish fellow believers.

cschildren.title: Parents are to admonish their children
Leaders are to admonish those in their care
Christians are to admonish fellow believers
It is wise to accept legitimate admonition

children.title: adorning
children.comment: A form of ornamentation, using especially jewels and precious metals, to enhance the beauty of buildings or people.

cschildren.title: Buildings were adorned with various materials
Women adorned themselves with jewellery and fine clothes
Personal adornment should not be allowed to detract from worship
Adorning used in a metaphorical sense

children.title: advice
children.comment: Counsel is essential for gaining wisdom, though human advice is not always reliable. God's advice is necessary and trustworthy for guidance in life.

children.title: A wise person seeks advice from others
Rejecting good advice can lead to disaster
Human advice can have unseen dangers

cschildren.title: Seeking advice from false gods is futile
God needs no-one to advise him

children.title: Through Jesus Christ and his Spirit
advisers
children.comment: Those who give advice and counsel. Human advice is desirable, but not always reliable. Only God's counsel is wholly dependable.

children.title: It is wise to consult advisers
It is folly to reject wise advisers
Advisers who trust in false gods must be rejected
The promised Messiah is an adviser
The Holy Spirit is an adviser

seealsos.comment: The Holy Spirit's counsel defends believers from every accusation and provides all necessary teaching and guidance.

children.title: affection
children.comment: Positive feelings towards another, often expressed in terms of attachment and warmth.

cschildren.title: Affection is sometimes expressed in familial terms

children.title: agony
children.comment: Intense suffering of body, mind or spirit, brought about by illness, death or the judgment of God.

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ prays on the Mount of Olives

children.title: agreement
children.comment: Being of one mind with others, whether for good or evil purposes. Agreement among believers is commended as a means of enhancing unity and peace, and building up the people of God.

children.title: amazement
children.comment: Astonishment and surprise are frequent responses to the actions and words of God and Jesus Christ.

seealsos.comment: The LORD promises to do amazing things when his people cross the Jordan
Nebuchadnezzar is amazed at seeing four men in the furnace

cschildren.title: Throughout his life Jesus Christ inspired amazement

children.title: In theological debate with the Sadducees
After talking with the rich young man
After the cleansing of the temple

primaryrefs.comment: Here the crowds' amazement causes the chief priests and teachers of the law to fear Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: Amazement at Jesus Christ's revelation of himself

seealsos.comment: at the healing of the paralytic
at the healing of Jairus' daughter
at the healing of the crippled beggar

secondaryrefs.comment: a boy with an evil spirit

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ walking on the water

cschildren.title: Amazement at the coming of the Holy Spirit and subsequent events

seealsos.comment: Simon's amazement at the miracles performed by Philip
amazement at the change in Saul
astonishment at the Holy Spirit being poured out on the Gentiles
amazement at Peter's release from prison

children.title: ambition
children.comment: A powerful personal drive towards achieving goals which are regarded as being of importance to the individual. Ambition is viewed negatively when these goals are selflish or evil, and positively when they are directed towards building up the church or furthering the kingdom of God.

children.title: ambition, negative aspects of
children.comment: In its negative sense, ambition is the pursuit of personal status and fortune, which is contrary to the purposes of God as expressed in Scripture.

children.title: Selfish ambition: a desire for personal aggrandisement
Selfish ambition arises from fallen human nature
ambition, positive aspects of
children.comment: In its positive sense, ambition is a personal desire for spiritual progress or achievement.

children.title: A longing for God and for what he can do in the believer
The desire for a leadership role in the church
The longing for communion with God
The compelling desire to preach the gospel

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ can be proclaimed, despite selfish personal ambition.

children.title: ambition, negative aspects of
children.comment: In its negative sense, ambition is the pursuit of personal status and fortune, which is contrary to the purposes of God as expressed in Scripture.

children.title: Selfish ambition: a desire for personal aggrandisement
Selfish ambition arises from fallen human nature
ambition, positive aspects of
children.comment: In its positive sense, ambition is a personal desire for spiritual progress or achievement.

children.title: A longing for God and for what he can do in the believer
The desire for a leadership role in the church
The longing for communion with God
The compelling desire to preach the gospel

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ can be proclaimed, despite selfish personal ambition.

children.title: anger
children.comment: A state of indignation and outrage, often resulting from distress caused by injustice or insult. Scripture affirms God's righteous anger against sin and urges moderation in regard to human anger.

children.title: anger, divine
children.comment: The anger of God is directed against all human sin, disobedience, rebellion and wickedness, which threaten to thwart his purposes for his creation and people.

children.title: The characteristics of God that provoke his anger
He is also compassionate and slow to anger
Being saved from the anger of God
God's anger cannot be averted by human means
God's anger is averted on account of his love for believers
God's anger is averted on account of the work of Jesus Christ
anger, human
children.comment: Human anger arises for a number of reasons, some of which are acceptable and others which are not. Scripture stresses the potentially destructive aspects of human anger and urges moderation.

primaryrefs.comment: Hanani had prophesied against the king.

children.title: anger, divine
children.comment: The anger of God is directed against all human sin, disobedience, rebellion and wickedness, which threaten to thwart his purposes for his creation and people.

children.title: The characteristics of God that provoke his anger
He is also compassionate and slow to anger
Being saved from the anger of God
God's anger cannot be averted by human means
God's anger is averted on account of his love for believers
God's anger is averted on account of the work of Jesus Christ
anger, human
children.comment: Human anger arises for a number of reasons, some of which are acceptable and others which are not. Scripture stresses the potentially destructive aspects of human anger and urges moderation.

primaryrefs.comment: Hanani had prophesied against the king.

children.title: appetite
children.comment: A hunger or desire for something. Although the primary reference of the term is to a hunger for food, it can also refer to other human desires. Scripture distinguishes between healthy and unhealthy appetites, indicating what it is appropriate to seek after.

cschildren.title: The gospel satisfies human hunger and thirst

children.title: arrogance
children.comment: Proud and unpleasant behaviour towards other people, based on a belief in one's own superiority or greater importance.

children.title: As an attitude of the heart

cschildren.title: Arrogance is essentially rebellion against God
Arrogance may even be found in the church

seealsos.comment: The LORD rejects Saul as king

children.title: asceticism
children.comment: Rigorous self-denial of bodily pleasures and needs. This can be motivated either by a praiseworthy desire to dedicate oneself completely to God, or by an erroneous belief that the physical body is evil.

children.title: The ascetic practice of wearing sackcloth and ashes
John's disciples, the Pharisees and asceticism
The Jews and the ascetic practice of regular fasting

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ refuses to enforce ascetic practices
Ascetic practice symbolises separation from the world and dedication to God

children.title: Asceticism as a sign of repentance
Rejection of fasting without true repentance
Asceticism not necessary for right worship and conduct

secondaryrefs.comment: Asceticism that is based on a negative view of the material world is rejected.

children.title: bereavement
children.comment: The experience or status of suffering the loss through death of a close relative or friend.

children.title: bereavement, experience of
children.comment: Scripture gives many examples of how people respond to the death of those they love.

primaryrefs.comment: At the news of the deaths of his sons and daughters.
Because of the death of his friend, Lazarus.

seealsos.comment: prediction of mourning for the Messiah

children.title: bereavement, God's comfort in
children.comment: God cares for the bereaved, and can turn their mourning into joy and hope.

children.title: God comforts the bereaved and the sorrowful

primaryrefs.comment: ``Falling asleep'' was a euphemistic way of talking about dying.

In the OT, death was generally feared because it meant the loss of meaningful existence. However, like several references, this one looks beyond the grave and anticipates NT hope for all who trust in God
Paul's conclusion after working through the implications of the gospel.

children.title: God's care for widows and orphans
Jesus Christ cared for the bereaved

primaryrefs.comment: At the grave of his friend, Lazarus.
Special provisions in the law for the bereaved

seealsos.comment: The early church provided for widows in the fellowship with a special fund

seealsos.comment: prediction of mourning for the Messiah

children.title: betrayal
children.comment: The treacherous exposing or deceiving of people by those they formerly trusted. It is usually associated with an enemy masquerading as a friend, or with a broken or abused relationship.  Betrayal was suffered by Jesus Christ and can be expected by his followers.

cschildren.title: Betrayal is part of human experience

seealsos.comment: Betrayal carries acute feelings for its victims

children.title: Examples of those murdered through betrayal
children.precomment: The power struggles of Israel's early kingship period gave rise to many bloody betrayals:

cschildren.title: Betrayal is seen as a particularly wicked act

children.title: Judas determines to betray Jesus Christ
Jesus Christ is betrayed by a kiss

primaryrefs.comment: The kiss featured in several betrayals as part of feigned friendship (see e.g., 2Sa 20:9-10 and Pr 27:6).

cschildren.title: Betrayal may be part of Christian experience
Betrayal as a sign of the end times
God never betrays those who trust in him

children.title: bitterness
children.comment: A feeling of anger and resentment, caused particularly by perceived unfairness in suffering or by adverse circumstances.

primaryrefs.comment: Because of the exiles' hardness of heart.

cschildren.title: Bitterness is evidence of a sinful heart

children.title: The causes of bitterness will pass away

cschildren.title: Examples of bitterness in people's lives

children.title: blasphemy
children.comment: The profaning, desecration and taking in vain of the name of God, or the reviling of any of his works or deeds. It is strongly forbidden by God as dishonouring to his name.

cschildren.title: Blasphemy against the Holy Spirit is unpardonable

children.title: Rejecting his word and his servants blasphemes God
Speaking against his people blasphemes God

secondaryrefs.comment: To persecute the church is to persecute Jesus Christ

cschildren.title: The sins of God's people may cause others to blaspheme

seealsos.comment: The phrase ``you have made the enemies of the LORD show utter contempt'' reflects a scribal tradition which avoided any reference to blasphemy. The underlying idea of blasphemy would have been obvious to the original readers

children.title: Jesus Christ falsely accused of blasphemy
God's servants falsely accused of blasphemy
brokenness
children.comment: God breaks the spirit of the proud and arrogant so that in their humility and brokenness they may come to repentance and restoration. A crushed heart or spirit may be caused by tragic circumstances or by God's judgment.

cschildren.title: Brokenness as a result of God's judgment

children.title: care
children.comment: A practical outworking of loving vigilance, efforts and tenderness. Care is perfectly shown by God. People should imitate God's care, but human care is often limited, faulty or misplaced in self-centred ways.

cschildren.title: Caring as part of God's character

seealsos.comment: God is the father in this parable.

children.title: Human care should reflect God's nature
God's care contrasted with human care

cschildren.title: God's care reflected in human relationships
To be careless or uncaring is wrong
Care for worldly things is wrong
God relieves his people of cares

primaryrefs.comment: There is a vital distinction between ``care'' in the sense of ``loving care'' which Christians are to practise, and ``worldly care'' in the sense of ``anxiety'' which Christians should transfer to God, since they and their needs are his responsibility.

children.title: carelessness
children.comment: A lack of attention to one's thoughts and deeds, or a failure to give adequate thought to the consequences of one's actions, often leading to distressing results.

children.title: charm
children.comment: The gracious effect of attracting and captivating others or the subtle ability to deceive and mislead them.

cschildren.title: Charm to attract and captivate others

children.title: The lovers in the Song of Solomon
The devil subtly seeks to deceive people

cschildren.title: False teachers use charm to deceive others

children.title: To draw people away from Jesus Christ
Christians must not be deceived by such charm
comfort
children.comment: The consolation and reassurance of those who are in distress, anxiety or need. Such comfort is an essential aspect of human relationships. Scripture declares that God comforts his people in times of distress.

cschildren.title: The comfort of friends and relations
Comfort as a specific work of the Holy Spirit

primaryrefs.comment: The title ``Counsellor'' may be translated ``Comforter''.

cschildren.title: Comfort within the fellowship of believers

children.title: compassion
children.comment: A quality of care and sympathy, characteristic of God and Jesus Christ, usually shown in acts of kindness and consideration towards those in any kind of difficulty or crisis.

children.title: compassion, human
children.comment: An attitude of care and concern, grounded in pity and sympathy towards others.  Christian compassion towards others should reflect the compassion of God for his people.

children.title: Compassion is a vital requirement in Christian character
Compassion needs to be shown in actions
compassion, human
children.comment: An attitude of care and concern, grounded in pity and sympathy towards others.  Christian compassion towards others should reflect the compassion of God for his people.

children.title: Compassion is a vital requirement in Christian character
Compassion needs to be shown in actions
complacency
children.comment: A self-satisfied state of negligence or carelessness, especially in relation to one's personal situation.

children.title: compromise
children.comment: Usually a combination of contrasting values, practices or persons incurring God's disapproval, but it can also be a positive way to achieve a greater good.

children.title: Israel was not to associate with paganism
Christians must not compromise their allegiance

primaryrefs.comment: The LORD's action in bringing Israel up out of Egypt is here attributed to the golden calves representing Baal.

cschildren.title: Examples of those who refused to compromise
Compromise as a mutually acceptable solution

children.title: For the sake of the gospel
concealment
children.comment: The deliberate hiding from view of a person, object or action. Those who sin against God often attempt to hide from him. The Bible teaches the need to confess sin and receive God's forgiveness. Nothing is concealed from him and all secrets will ultimately be revealed.

cschildren.title: Attempted concealment of sin from God

children.title: No sin can be concealed from God
Sins should be confessed to God and not concealed

cschildren.title: Believers should not conceal their light

primaryrefs.comment: Christ is the mystery of God, which has now been made known. Through faith, believers share in this mystery.

children.title: conceit
children.comment: A state of pride arising out of an overestimation of one's own ability, possessions or importance.

cschildren.title: The danger of conceit for Christians

children.title: Being prepared to mix with the lowly

cschildren.title: Confrontation between Jesus Christ and the Pharisees

children.title: confusion
children.comment: A state of perplexity, bewilderment or disorder. Confusion may be brought about by God to cause the schemes of the wicked to fail and opposition to his people to prove ineffective. Confusion over spiritual truth is the natural state of humanity; believers, too, may be perplexed by God's purposes or thrown into confusion by false teaching.

children.title: The righteous ask God to confuse their enemies
God sends confusion on Israel's enemies

cschildren.title: Spiritual confusion is humanity's natural state
Further examples of believers in confusion

children.title: Confusion dispelled by asking God for understanding
Confusion dispelled by the enlightenment of the Holy Spirit
Confusion combated by the teaching of wise leaders
Confusion dispelled by the instruction of Scripture
Confusion goes as believers grow to spiritual maturity
consciousness
children.comment: The state of being aware, especially of one's actions and motivations, or of the existence and concerns of others. All people have a general awareness or consciousness of God and of sin, but it is often suppressed or destroyed.

children.title: Through the convicting power of the Holy Spirit
Through an innate knowledge of the creator
Through the revelation of God in nature
conspiracies
children.comment: Malicious plots or plans to harm or to kill, which may be directed against other people, or even against God. Conspiracies are sometimes motivated by political aspirations, but may be simply an outlet for wrongdoing.

cschildren.title: Conspiracies to hinder the work of God

children.title: False accusations of conspiracy against kings
contempt
children.comment: An attitude of scorn and derision. Examples are given of the way in which a rebellious and fallen world treats its creator with contempt.

cschildren.title: Contempt of some people for others

children.title: Sanballat, Geshem and Tobiah for Nehemiah's men

cschildren.title: God will bring contempt on his people
Jesus Christ as the object of contempt

children.title: cowardice
children.comment: An unwillingness to act in a situation of danger or opposition, because of fear. Avoiding the source of one's anxiety or fear, rather than dealing with it directly.

cschildren.title: Cowardice prevents people from acknowledging Jesus Christ publicly

seealsos.comment: parents of the man born blind

children.title: Cowardice inhibits bad as well as good behaviour
Cowardice leads to avoidance of the difficulty

seealsos.comment: after the destruction of the pigs

children.title: Cowardice can spread within a group

cschildren.title: God gives hope to the cowardly or fearful

primaryrefs.comment: Where cowardice meant rejecting the gospel and denying Jesus Christ.

children.title: criticism
children.comment: The judgment or evaluation of others. The word often has negative associations, implying a harsh or disapproving estimate of people or their actions.

children.title: criticism, amongst believers
children.comment: Harsh criticism is out of place among believers, who are urged to see each other in the best possible light. Criticism of God arises from a failure to understand his actions and purposes.

children.title: Criticism can be dealt with by settling the dispute
Integrity is a defence against criticism
Criticism and complaint directed against God
Criticism of God for his apparent injustice
Criticism of God for his apparent disregard of his people's plight
criticism, against believers
children.comment: Many notable servants of God were subject to criticism, which was sometimes vicious and severe. This was particularly true of Jesus Christ, who was constantly subject to complaint and criticism.

children.title: Examples of criticism directed against believers
Jesus Christ criticised by his family
Jesus Christ criticised by his disciples
Jesus Christ criticised by the Pharisees
Jesus Christ criticised for his teaching
criticism, amongst believers
children.comment: Harsh criticism is out of place among believers, who are urged to see each other in the best possible light. Criticism of God arises from a failure to understand his actions and purposes.

children.title: Criticism can be dealt with by settling the dispute
Integrity is a defence against criticism

Criticism of God for his apparent injustice
Criticism of God for his apparent disregard of his people's plight
criticism, against believers
children.comment: Many notable servants of God were subject to criticism, which was sometimes vicious and severe. This was particularly true of Jesus Christ, who was constantly subject to complaint and criticism.

children.title: Examples of criticism directed against believers
Jesus Christ criticised by his family
Jesus Christ criticised by his disciples
Jesus Christ criticised by the Pharisees
Jesus Christ criticised for his teaching
cruelty
children.comment: Behaviour in which pain or suffering is deliberately inflicted on others, especially the weak and defenceless.

children.title: cruelty, examples of
children.comment: Scripture condemns cruelty, and gives examples of situations in which it was practised.

children.title: Cruelty is an expression of wickedness

secondaryrefs.comment: Judah's cruelty to a local king

children.title: cruelty, God's attitude to
children.comment: God condemns cruelty. As part of the work of redemption, God suffers cruelty from the world in order to redeem believers.

children.title: God allows cruelty as part of his judgment

seealsos.comment: The LORD promises cruel judgment on those who disobey his laws

children.title: cruelty, examples of
children.comment: Scripture condemns cruelty, and gives examples of situations in which it was practised.

children.title: Cruelty is an expression of wickedness

secondaryrefs.comment: Judah's cruelty to a local king

children.title: cruelty, God's attitude to
children.comment: God condemns cruelty. As part of the work of redemption, God suffers cruelty from the world in order to redeem believers.

children.title: God allows cruelty as part of his judgment

seealsos.comment: The LORD promises cruel judgment on those who disobey his laws

children.title: curse
children.comment: An expression of contempt or malediction for someone. To be cursed is to suffer various kinds of misfortune, sometimes to the extent of being cut off from one's family or community, or of suffering death itself.

children.title: Divine curses came into effect after the fall

seealsos.comment: This curse refers to the flood; the curse of Ge 3:17 is not revoked here.

children.title: Divine curses come from disobeying the law
Human curses upon other human beings
Human beings are forbidden to curse God and others

cschildren.title: People can curse the day they were born
Paul wishes himself cursed for the sake of Israel
Jesus Christ took the curse of the law upon himself
Christians are exhorted to bless those who curse them

children.title: danger
children.comment: A condition of threat, physical or spiritual, in which evil, malice, accident or destruction looms.

children.title: Danger does not overcome the faithful
defiance
children.comment: Open refusal to obey any authority. Defiance is seen in the Bible as evil when authority is legitimate but good when authority is ungodly.

children.title: To defy God's people is to defy God
delight
children.comment: A sense of joy and pleasure, experienced especially through achievements or relationships.

cschildren.title: God as the source of delight

children.title: Delight in the person of God
Delight in the word of God
Delight in the works of God
God's delight is absent when something is viewed unfavourably

cschildren.title: The delight of believers in their relationship with God

children.title: depression
children.comment: A deep sense of despondency, discouragement and sadness, often linked with a sense of personal powerlessness and a loss of meaning in and enthusiasm for life. Many biblical characters show evidence of such behaviour which originates in a number of different ways.

children.title: A sense of the futility of life
Loss of sense of God's presence
A loathing of life and a desire to end it
Renewed vision of God and being centred upon him
desire
children.comment: A sense of longing for or wanting something. It may be a positive or negative force in the human character, but sinful desire is characteristic of human nature and must be overcome by the believer. God also expresses desires in Scripture.

children.title: Sinful desire is inherent in human nature
Following Jesus Christ means putting to death sinful desires

cschildren.title: The tension in believers between the desires of the old and new natures

children.title: diligence
children.comment: Conscientious hard work and perseverance, particularly with regard to a relationship with God. In Scripture diligence is highly commended. It may, however, be misguided.

cschildren.title: Diligence and its results are commended

seealsos.comment: characteristic of the wife of noble character
regarding the collection for the poor Christians in Jerusalem

cschildren.title: Diligence is important in the outworking of one's relationship with God
Diligence was a characteristic of Jesus Christ's mission

children.title: disagreement
children.comment: A failure to be of one mind, which should be avoided whenever possible within the church, the family and other areas of everyday life. Christians are urged to maintain the unity of the church and avoid damaging division.

primaryrefs.comment: The background to this statement is Dt 19:15, which demands that conviction can only take place on the testimony of two or three agreed witnesses.

secondaryrefs.comment: Nahash's suggestion to the men of Jabesh Gilead
Abraham and Lot resolve their disagreement over land and livestock
Isaac settles a disagreement about the water supply
Solomon resolves a disagreement between two prostitutes.

primaryrefs.comment: Moses realised that he was unable to deal with all the people's disputes alone.

cschildren.title: Those who seek to resolve disagreement are blessed

children.title: disappointment
children.comment: The sadness experienced when people or circumstances do not fulfil expectations.

cschildren.title: Disappointment caused by people or circumstances
Disappointment as a result of not understanding God's purposes
Disappointment as the result of sin

secondaryrefs.comment: David and his men at Ziklag
Paul's possible disappointment with the Corinthians

cschildren.title: God does not disappoint his faithful people

children.title: disgrace
children.comment: Shame and dishonour that can arise from sin and idolatry. The exile of Israel brought disgrace upon God's name. God's people may suffer disgrace for the sake of Jesus Christ.

children.title: Brought on Israel
children.precomment: As the result of Achan stealing what was dedicated to God:

secondaryrefs.comment: as the result of Goliath's boasting
when God no longer acted on Israel's behalf

cschildren.title: The exile brought disgrace upon God's name
God's people may suffer disgrace for the sake of Jesus Christ
The hiding of one's personal identity for a variety of reasons

children.title: disrespect

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote ``only begotten'' indicates that Jesus Christ is the unique Son of God, in origin, eternity and nature.

children.title: As the mediator between God and humanity
unkindness
children.comment: Unsympathetic or cruel behaviour. It is contrary to God's character and is condemned in Scripture.

cschildren.title: God's kindness as a model for believers

children.title: unreliability
children.comment: The quality of a person or thing that cannot be trusted or relied upon. Scripture notes the unreliability of human nature, while stressing the total reliability of God.

children.title: Unreliable people are not to be trusted
value
children.comment: God places inestimable value on the human soul. He paid the redemption price of the blood of his son Jesus Christ to purchase his own people who are precious to him. Everything that achieves or maintains this relationship is to be valued.

cschildren.title: Redemptive values of people, animals and property

secondaryrefs.comment: These are the values for recovering or buying back what has been dedicated to God.  They were designed to teach the Israelites the great cost of redemption.

children.title: They are made in the image of God

primaryrefs.comment: Being made in God's image gives humanity intrinsic worth and dignity.

children.title: The inestimable value of a human soul
The redemptive price of a soul
The value of God's people to him

cschildren.title: The value of Christian life and service

children.title: violence
children.comment: Unrestrained physical or verbal force designed to hurt others, or to gain mastery over them.

cschildren.title: The world is full of violence
Christian leaders should not be violent
God helps the victims of violence
Christians should help the victims of violence

children.title: visiting
children.comment: Calling to see a person or place. Examples include pilgrims to Jerusalem and those visiting family and friends. Visiting those in need, especially the sick and bereaved, is particularly important. Individuals and churches are encouraged and strengthened by visits from other believers.

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ visits his home region of Galilee.

children.title: waiting
children.comment: Being in readiness for service or for some future appointment or event. Wild animals and the wicked lie in wait to ambush the unsuspecting; servants wait on their masters; believers and the whole creation wait for their renewal by God. God, too, waits for sinners to repent.

children.title: Waiting for a period of time
Waiting to be joined by others
Believers and creation wait for renewal
The wicked lie in wait for God's servants

seealsos.comment: The Philistines lay in wait for Samson
Jeremiah's enemies were looking for an opportunity against him
Some Jews were waiting to kill Paul.

children.title: Jesus Christ's enemies waited to trap him
Animals lie in wait for prey

cschildren.title: God waits for sinners to repent

children.title: warning
children.comment: Telling someone of coming disaster or danger or of the consequences of their action or attitude. Scripture gives strong warnings against idolatry, sin and false teaching.

cschildren.title: Warnings of coming disaster or danger

children.title: waste
children.comment: The misuse and squandering of resources. God condemns the waste of resources which he provides, especially spiritual provisions such as grace and opportunity. Sometimes extravagance in God's service is mistaken for waste.

children.title: As a consequence of yielding to temptation

cschildren.title: Spiritual resources should not be wasted

primaryrefs.comment: Spiritual teaching is wasted if inappropriate to the spiritual capacity of the hearers.

children.title: Esau
children.precomment: Esau lived for the pleasures of the moment and threw away his spiritual inheritance:

secondaryrefs.comment: Though Samson did retrieve something at the end of his life, his spiritual gift of supernatural strength was largely wasted through his indulgence in sexual immorality.

Through natural strength and spiritual gifts Saul had the prospect of establishing a successful royal dynasty. The future was lost through disobedience and the end of his reign was wasted through jealousy.
Judas had the best of opportunities--three years with Jesus Christ. This was thrown away in a moment of personal ambition.

cschildren.title: Devotion to God is not waste
Waste as the destruction of life and land

children.title: Waste as a result of the judgment of God
